top_comment.text:
We need another Internet. Here's my two cents and please contribute.
AS: These ideas are not mine. I just put 2 and 2 together. Decentralized 
planning and ad-hoc systems are all around. I just copied a pattern of 
thought. 
Basic idea: We have ipv6 already written aka 2 to the power of 128 ips 
(basically unlimited). think about it this way, if we would change the code 
so as gateways are setup ad-hoc, not needing a central authority to 
dispatch ips, pretty much like bitcoin, like you boot up your wifi router 
and it finds others and politely asks to join them, then all the wifi 
routers using this protocol would wire themselves randomly and you would 
not know what router you are connected to or you would be connect to many 
which instead would connect to others and so on. Your connections would 
reach the destination using all possible routes at once. How can you sniff 
that when all you receive are sparse packets, probably not even in the 
right order if any? Need more net? buy more routers and spread them around. 
They would not be in your possession but rather a common shared resource 
which would only require electricity. If one of them would try to get the 
identity of another, it would just get rejected by the others because of 
the negotiation algorithm. See how bitcoin works to figure out how to 
distribute IPs/IP ranges uniquely and without theft/impersonation. you 
could have roaming, aka bye bye gsm and your communications would be hard 
if not impossible to spy on, even when unencrypted (unless the bastard has 
you wired). It's not scifi, it's doable at least on a citywide level and 
the speeds would be unbelievably faster then what we have today. Plus it 
works in parallel with what we have today. You would not even know which 
line you're using, say for the speed improvement.
I want to start working on this after I finish my current project which is 
just as important but if someone is nice enough to do it, be my guest. It's 
a cool project and you would get more infamous then Steve Jobs as the man 
who put a stop to censorship, completely replaced GSM and made internet 
un-taxable, and as accessible as a chat with your friends.﻿

top_comment.text:
5:30

Crony capitalism is the logical destination of capitalism. Destroying the 
opportunities of other firms is part of the competition for capital 
accumulation & market shares, and the state is the strongest enabler of 
such destruction. Private ownership of capital & market shares are 
inherently exclusive. If a company wins in a freemarket, it gains financial 
advantages over the others, and the capitalist principle of competition 
dictates that the gains be invested in securing the company's business at 
the expense of the competitors, which includes strategic destruction of the 
conditions of freemarket itself. It's by approaching full-fledged 
capitalism that big corporations capitalize on the state apparatus to 
destroy the freemarket.﻿
top_comment.author: Miranda N

comments.text:
+Triangleman3
Yes, I agree. And my point (in response to Cenk's argument that regulations 
can secure capitalism) is:

Preventing corporations from freely using (capitalizing on) their resources 
in the competition for market shares, is anti-capitalism.

Cenk is mistaking the condition of fair exposition of market commodities 
for capitalism itself, when strategic efforts to destroy that condition of 
"freemarket" (e.g. lobbying) is part of the competition for a capitalist 
success (i.e. accumulation of capital & expansion of market shares).
comments.author: Miranda N

comments.text:
I'm not sure that what you're saying pertains to my point. I mean that laws 
and regulations can be instituted to prevent corporations from having any 
power in the government. For example, you could ban private money from all 
elections, ban lobbyists, prevent major corporations from effecting public 
opinion etc...
comments.author: Triangleman3

comments.text:
+Triangleman3
Proper regulations, which I support, can help equal exposition of companies 
& their products in markets, yes. But it does so by prohibiting larger 
companies from freely capitalizing on their unmatched resources in the 
competition for market shares. That is, fair market exposition is assisted 
by limiting the freedom of capitalization so that there is no full-scale 
competition of capital among the companies that would result in a biased 
exposition.

I'm pointing out, as a non-capitalist, that what Cenk is arguing for is not 
capitalism.
comments.author: Miranda N

comments.text:
If only the market were so free.

I believe what you're missing here is that there are only seven Tier1 
internet providers in the US: Level 3 Communications,TeliaSonera 
International Carrier, CenturyLink, Vodafone, Verizon, Sprint, and AT&T 
Corporation.

Tier1 internet is the backbone of the internet, and most ISPs lease a 
portion of this backbone to resell to consumers. Those who control the 
backbone control the entire flow of traffic, and so it is these 
mega-corporations which would have to implement this policy in order for it 
to work. Otherwise, what they filter or throttle will trickle down to every 
ISP who leases from them by default.
